question: How can consuming candy ultimately lead to the presence of alcohol in the body, and what role does sugar play in this process?
gold_answer: Candy contains sugar, and sugar is changed into alcohol.
llm_answer: The context does not describe any process in which eating candy turns into alcohol inside the human body; it only explains that the sugar in fruit-juice can turn into alcohol when the juice is left to ferment outside the body. Therefore, based on the given passages, consuming candy does not ultimately lead to alcohol forming within the body.

context.text: How does it affect his manners? [Illustration: _Bones of the human body._] CHAPTER IV. WHAT IS ALCOHOL? [Illustration: R]IPE grapes are full of juice. This juice is mostly water, sweetened with a sugar of its own. It is flavored with something which makes us know, the moment we taste it, that it is grape-juice, and not cherry-juice or plum-juice. Apples also contain water, sugar, and apple flavor; and cherries contain water, sugar, and cherry flavor. The same is true of other fruits. They all, when ripe, have the water and the sugar; and each has a flavor of its own. Ripe grapes are sometimes gathered and put into great tubs called vats. In these the juice is squeezed out. In some countries, this squeezing is done by bare-footed men who jump into the vats and press the grapes with their feet. The grape-juice is then drawn off from the skins and seeds and left standing in a warm place. Bubbles soon begin to rise and cover the top of it with froth. The juice is all in motion. [Illustration: _Picking grapes and making wine._] If the cook had wished to use this grape-juice to make jelly, she would say: "Now, I can not make my grape-jelly, for the grape-juice is spoiled." WHAT

unripe apples. CANDY. Most children like candy so well, that they are in danger of eating more sugar than is good for them. You would starve if fed only on sugar. We would not need to be quite so much afraid of a little candy if it were not for the poison with which it is often . Even what is called pure, white candy is sometimes not really such. There is a simple way by which you can find this out for yourselves. If you put a spoonful of sugar into a tumbler of water, it will all dissolve and disappear. Put a piece of white candy into a tumbler of water; and, if it is made of pure sugar only, it will dissolve and disappear. If it is not, you will find at the bottom of the tumbler some white earth. This is not good food for anybody. Candy-makers often put it into candy in place of sugar, because it is cheaper than sugar. REVIEW QUESTIONS.           1. Why do we need food?           2. How do people get water to drink?           3. Why is it not safe to drink water that has been           standing in lead pipes?           4. Why is the water of a well

When you next try to pick a "drum-stick," remember that you are eating the strong muscles by which the chicken or turkey moved his legs as he walked about the yard. The parts that have the most work to do, need the strongest muscles. Did you ever see the swallows flying about the eaves of a barn? Do they have very stout legs? No! They have very small legs and feet, because they do not need to walk. They need to fly. The muscles that move the wings are fastened to the breast. These breast muscles of the swallow must be large and strong. EXERCISE OF THE MUSCLES. People who work hard with any part of the body make the muscles of that part very strong. The blacksmith has big, strong muscles in his arms because he uses them so much. You are using your muscles every day, and this helps them to grow. Once I saw a little girl who had been very sick. She had to lie in bed for many weeks. Before her sickness she had plenty of stout muscles in her arms and legs and was running about the house from morning till night, carrying her big doll in her arms. After her sickness, she could hardly walk ten steps, and would rather sit and look at her playthings than try to lift them. She had to make new muscles as fast as possible. Running, coasting, games of ball, and all brisk play and work, help to make strong muscles.

to make jelly, she would say: "Now, I can not make my grape-jelly, for the grape-juice is spoiled." WHAT IS THIS CHANGE IN THE GRAPE-JUICE? The sugar in the grape-juice is changing into something else. It is turning into alcohol and a gas[A] that moves about in little bubbles in the liquid, and rising to the top, goes off into the air. The alcohol is a thin liquid which, mixed with the water, remains in the grape-juice. The sugar is gone; alcohol and the bubbles of gas are left in its place. This alcohol is a liquid poison. A little of it will harm any one who drinks it; much of it would kill the drinker. Ripe grapes are good food; but grape-juice, when its sugar has turned to alcohol, is not a safe drink for any one. It is poisoned by the alcohol. WINE. This changed grape-juice is called wine. It is partly water, partly alcohol, and it still has the grape flavor in it. Wine is also made from currants, elderberries, and other fruits, in very much the same way as from grapes. People sometimes make it at home from the fruits that grow in their own gardens, and think there is no alcohol in it, because they do not put any in. But you know that the alcohol is made in the fruit-juice itself by the change of the sugar

the body which need it, comes from fat-making foods. In cold weather, we need more fatty food than we do in summer, just as in cold countries people need such food all the time. The Esquimaux, who live in the lands of snow and ice, catch a great many walrus and seal, and eat a great deal of fat meat. You would not be well unless you ate some fat or butter or oil. WHAT WILL MAKE FAT? Sugar will make fat, and so will starch, cream, rice, butter, and fat meat. As milk will make muscle and fat and bones, it is the best kind of food. Here, again, it is the earth that sends us our food. Fat meat comes from animals well fed on grain and grass; sugar, from sugar-cane, maple-trees, or beets; oil, from olive-trees; butter, from cream; and starch, from potatoes, and from corn, rice, and other grains. Green apples and other unripe fruits are not yet ready to be eaten. The starch which we take for food has to be changed into sugar, before it can mix with the blood and help feed the body. As the sun ripens fruit, it changes its starch to sugar. You can tell this by the difference in the taste of ripe and unripe apples. CANDY. Most children like candy so well, that they are in danger of eating more sugar than is good for them.

in a place where he can watch it, and stop the sprouting just in time to save the sugar, before it is used to feed the root and stem. This sprouted grain is called malt. The brewer soaks it in plenty of water, because the grain has not water in itself, as the grape has. He puts in some yeast to help start the work of changing the sugar into gas[B] and alcohol. Sometimes hops are also put in, to give it a bitter taste. The brewer watches to see the bubbles of gas that tell, as plainly as words could, that sugar is going and alcohol is coming. When the work is finished, the barley has been made into beer. It might have been ground and made into barley-cakes, or into pearl barley to thicken our soups, and then it would have been good food. Now, it is a drink containing alcohol, and alcohol is a poison. You should not drink beer, because there is alcohol in it. Two boys of the same age begin school together. One of them drinks wine, cider, and beer. The other never allows these drinks to pass his lips. These boys soon become very different from each other, because one is poisoning his body and mind with alcohol, and the other is not. A man wants a good, steady boy to work for him. Which of these two do you think he will select? A few years later, a young man is wanted who can be trusted

MUSCLES. [Illustration: W]HAT makes the limbs move? You have to take hold of the door to move it back and forth; but you need not take hold of your arm to move that. What makes it move? Sometimes a door or gate is made to shut itself, if you leave it open. This can be done by means of a wide rubber strap, one end of which is fastened to the frame of the door near the hinge, and the other end to the door, out near its edge. When we push open the door, the rubber strap is stretched; but as soon as we have passed through, the strap tightens, draws the door back, and shuts it. If you stretch out your right arm, and clasp the upper part tightly with your left hand, then work the elbow joint strongly back and forth, you can feel something under your hand draw up, and then lengthen out again, each time you bend the joint. What you feel, is a muscle (m[)u]s'sl), and it works your joints very much as the rubber

communities.summary:
1. **Title**: Effects of Alcohol Consumption
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the negative effects of alcohol consumption on the human body. Alcohol is formed through the fermentation of sugar in fruit juices, such as grape and apple, and can be found in drinks like wine and cider. Consuming alcohol can lead to addiction, harm the body and mind, and even cause death. The texts also touch on the importance of a healthy diet and the role of different food groups in maintaining a strong body. Additionally, the dangers of tobacco use and the importance of avoiding harmful substances are mentioned. Overall, the texts emphasize the need for responsible behavior and healthy habits to maintain overall well-being.
3. **Keywords**: Alcohol, Addiction, Health, Nutrition, Tobacco

1. **Health and Nutrition**
2. The provided text chunks discuss the importance of a healthy diet and lifestyle, highlighting the benefits of consuming nutritious food and avoiding harmful substances like alcohol. The chunks also explain how the body works, including the conversion of starch into sugar and the role of the heart. Additionally, they emphasize the negative effects of alcohol on the body and mind, including its impact on strength and overall well-being. The text also touches on the composition of bones and the importance of a balanced diet. Furthermore, it discusses the dangers of alcohol and the benefits of a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise and a balanced diet.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Nutrition, Alcohol, Strength, Body

1. **Title**: Health and Substance Abuse
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the importance of maintaining good health, particularly during childhood and adolescence. They warn against the dangers of substance abuse, such as tobacco and alcohol, which can have severe and long-lasting effects on the body. The chunks also provide guidance on how to care for various parts of the body, including the eyes, ears, and spine, and emphasize the need for healthy habits and responsible decision-making. The overall theme is one of promoting healthy lifestyles and warning against the risks associated with substance abuse. The text also highlights the importance of self-care and responsible behavior, particularly during childhood and adolescence, in order to maintain good physical and mental health.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Substance Abuse, Tobacco, Alcohol, Wellness

1. **Title**: Health and Body Care
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss various aspects of health and body care, including the importance of taking care of one's teeth, the dangers of narcotics and tobacco, and the need to maintain a healthy body temperature. The chunks also touch on the negative effects of alcohol and tobacco on the body and the importance of dressing warmly in cold weather. Additionally, the text highlights the financial costs of tobacco and alcohol, emphasizing that money spent on these substances is wasted and can have negative consequences.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Body Care, Tobacco, Alcohol, Narcotics

1. **Title**: Health and Body Functions
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss various aspects of human health and body functions, including the importance of fresh air, the role of the lungs, heart, and skin, and the effects of alcohol on the body. The texts also touch on the importance of proper hygiene, such as airing clothes and beds, and the need to avoid close rooms and impure air. Additionally, the chunks warn about the dangers of alcohol consumption and its impact on the body and mind. Overall, the texts aim to educate readers about the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle and avoiding harmful substances.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Body Functions, Alcohol, Hygiene, Respiratory System

1. **Human Anatomy Basics**
2. The provided text chunks discuss the fundamental components of the human body, including muscles, bones, and nerves. Muscles are described as lean meat that works joints, similar to a rubber strap working a door hinge. The importance of exercise in strengthening muscles is emphasized, and the negative effects of alcohol and idleness on muscle health are noted. The text also touches on the structure and function of bones, including the spine and joints, and the role of nerves in sending messages throughout the body.
3. **Keywords**: Human Anatomy, Muscles, Bones, Nerves

1. **Human Physiology Basics**
2. The provided text chunks discuss fundamental concepts of human physiology, including joints, bones, muscles, nerves, and the effects of substances like alcohol and tobacco on the body. The texts appear to be from an educational book, aiming to teach children about the human body and its functions in a simple and practical manner. The book covers various topics, such as the importance of hygiene, the role of organs, and the need for proper nutrition. The overall goal is to provide children with a basic understanding of human physiology and promote healthy habits.
3. **Keywords**: Human Physiology, Health Education, Hygiene

1. **Title**: Industrial Machinery and Innovations
2. **Summary**: The collection of text chunks discusses various industrial machinery and innovations, including improved gas engines, bone-black revivifying plants, and hank sizing machines. These machines are designed to increase efficiency and productivity in different industries, such as manufacturing and textiles. The texts also describe the technical details of these machines, including their components, mechanisms, and operating principles. Additionally, some texts mention the potential applications and benefits of these innovations, such as improving the quality of drinking water and enabling the production of certain goods.
3. **Keywords**: Industrial Machinery, Innovations, Manufacturing, Textiles, Gas Engines

1. **Title**: The Nature of Bad Temper
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the complexities of a person's bad temper, specifically that of a character named Touchwood. His temper is described as pugnacious and contradicting, often leading to hurtful behavior towards others. Despite this, he is capable of sympathy and kindness, but his attempts at making amends often come across as insincere. The text also touches on the idea that individuals with uncertain tempers may believe it adds to their charm, but in reality, it can be repulsive and damaging to relationships. Furthermore, the discussion extends to the concept of how such temperaments can affect public figures and writers, leading to a lack of genuine impressions and a tendency to prioritize self-image over meaningful contributions.
3. **Keywords**: Bad Temper, Relationships, Insincerity, Public Figures, Self-Image
